review_blob: 330 mL bottle. Slightly hazy, bright orange, with a medium, bubbly, white head. The nose is bread dough, bubblegum, cinnamon, oregano, and candied orange peel. Sweet and pleasantly yeasty, with a strong earthy and herbal bitterness. Medium body, creamy, sticky, with a lingering bitter aftertaste. This is a wonderfully aromatic and well balanced beer. Unique and complex, yet easy and approachable.
UPDATED: APR 25, 2016

Bottle off the discount table at Downtown liquor. Pours a dark, amber color, with a big, bubbly beige head. The nose is raisins, cinnamon, brown sugar, butter toffee, and light licorice. Sweet and malty, with a light, earthy bitterness. Medium body, chalky, syrupy, fairly effervescent, and clean. This is a nice malt bomb, with good savory spiciness. Almost reminiscent of mulled cider. Quite delicious!

On tap at the brewery. Hazy, bright yellow color, with a small, off-white head and some lacing. Good, mellow lemon, cloves, and biscuit dough. Sweet, very yeasty, with a light citrusy tartness. Light to medium body, crisp, acidic, and creamy. This is a surprisingly nice hefeweizen, with lots of yeasty esters.

On tap at the brewery. Black, with a small, bubbly beige head. The nose is light coffee and cocoa, with some chicory, and a bit of coconut. The coconut comes forward strong in the mouth, surprisingly, because it is so faint in the aroma. Very sweet, with a nice earthy bitterness to balance. Heavy body, oily, thick and sticky. This is a fun and very coconut forward beer.

On tap at the brewery. Black, with a small, creamy beige head. The nose is light coffee, coconut water, melons, peat, and slightly floral. Medium to heavy body, syrupy, chalky, and thick. This is a roast forward beer, with very little bitterness.

On tap at the brewery. Dark ruby brown, with a small, persistent, tan head, and thick lacing The nose is maple syrup, vanilla, light coffee, and anise. Very sweet and boozy, with a mild, easy bitterness. Heavy body, syrupy, thick, and chewy. This is a fun and boozy beer, but a little strong on the barrel.

Sample, just after the non-blueberry version. Noticeably darker color, and almost purple. The nose is strong berry, which cuts out the funkiness and makes for a solid, enticing berries and cream character. Not really any sweeter or more sour, but the berries do up the acidity a bit. This makes me believe that this beer was made to have blueberries in it. Delicious, fruity, and creamy.

Sample. Pours a hazy, light brown, with a small, creamy, beige head. The nose is buttermilk or some kind of sharp cheese, with some lemon, caramel, and ripe apples. Sweet up front, with a decidedly funky finish. Medium body, creamy, thick, and lightly acidic. This is a pretty good sour, but the lacto is overdone, and the nose is almost, but not quite, off-putting.

Sampled from a 500 mL bottle. Pours a clear, bubbly brown, with a gigantic, foamy, beige head. Seriously wont stop producing foam. Give it a 10 minutes, and have a towel handy. The nose is subdued, due to the foam, but pretty nice, with notes of butter toffee and caramel, maple syrup, sour cherries, and cloves. The flavor is sweet and sugary, with a nice, mellow sourness through the finish. Light to medium body, syrupy, sticky, and acidic. This is a fair sour, but with some pretty interesting character and a solid, balanced flavor.

Sample from a 500 mL bottle. Pale, goldish hue, with a massive, foamy, off-white head. The nose is mellow honeydew, tangerine, riesling, and dry grass. Bone dry, with a touch of bitterness. Light body, lightly acidic, very astringent, and bubbly. This is a thoroughly interesting beer. About the driest beer Ive ever tried, yet easy and wonderfully flavorful.

On tap at the brewery. Unclear brown pour, with a small, beige head. The nose is toffee, black bread, juniper berries, anise, and black pepper. Malty and pretty sweet, with a fairly significant bitterness. Medium body, chalky, bready, and a little astringent. More akin to a hoppy brown, but with some good English malts going on. Unusual, but pretty tasty.
beer_name: Gold Camp Queen Palmers English Mild

review_blob: On tap at the brewery. Pours a slightly unclear, pale yellow color, with a medium, creamy, beige head. The nose is mild lemon cream, honey, and some floral notes. The flavor is a little sweet, with a good, subtle bitterness. Light body, a little syrupy, flat, and acidic. This is a fairly interesting, light beer, but very little sourness. Pretty good initial nose, but no complexity.

Sample at the brewery. Hazy, light gold color, with a fairly dense, off-white head. The nose is biscuit dough, light stone fruit, ripe bananas, and white bread. The flavor is sweet and yeasty, lightly acidic and tart, with a light, off-dry finish. Light to medium body, creamy, sharp, and clean. This is a pretty nice wheat; the yeasty esters are a little overdone, but the crisp, dry finish is excellent. The plum is barely there, in my opinion, but thats okay with me.
beer_name: Gold Camp The Bee Sting Plum Wheat

review_blob: 16 oz. can, in a free box from jackl. Pours pale yellow, with a medium, off-white, bubbly head. The nose is orange peel, heavy cloves, butter toffee, light cinnamon, and oregano. Sweet and herbal, with a sharp, pleasant bitterness. Long, sticky, bitter aftertaste. Medium body, acidic, lightly carbonated, and crisp. This is a surprisingly delicious beer, with great aroma and nicely balanced flavor.

Crowler from jackl. Light, bubbly yellow, with a big, off-white head and some lacing. The aroma is tangerines, lemon peel, coriander, and light overripe banana. Wheat sweetness up front, with a good, smooth bitterness that lingers in a pleasant aftertaste. The palate is pretty light, crisp, a little acidic, and sharp. This is a refreshing and easy IPA, with great hopping and good balance.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark copper color, with a medium, foamy, beige head. The nose is wheat bread, grapefruit, oak, a bit of cocoa, with some strong tannins and sour cherry notes coming forward as it warms. Sweet and citrusy, with a heavy bitterness and a light sour, vinous touch. Heavy body, lightly acidic, syrupy, and astringent. This is a very creative and well made beer, and the barrels ratchet up the complexity considerably. Very aromatic and flavorful.
beer_name: Nano 108 Port and Madeira Wine Barrel Aged House IPA (Version 1)

review_blob: Sampled at the brewery. Dark reddish brown color, with a big, beige head and some good lacing. The nose is dominated by the citrusy and earthy hops, with a distinct cedar character that is most evident when held in the mouth. The finish has notes of resin and pine. Sweet and malty, with a strong bitterness that lingers. Heavy body, thick, acerbic, and chewy. This is a distinctive and wonderfully aromatic beer, and the cedar adds a very fun twist to a solid IPA base.

Short pour at the brewery. Slightly unclear copper color, with a small, beige head. The nose is hay, a bit of apple, cloves, and a mild hickory smokiness. Sweet and phenolic, with a touch of bitterness. Light body, creamy, a bit acidic, and a little sticky. This is a fun and easy smoked beer, with enough to pique my interest, without feeling like Im drinking liquid bacon.

Short pour on nitro at the brewery. Clear ruby brown color, with a medium, tan, foamy, nitro head. The nose is bready and toffee malts, with some light smoke and peat, rosemary, and licorice. Sweet and malty, with a good, mellow bitterness through the finish. Medium body, velvety and lush. This is a very enjoyable, light malty beer. Good balance and fantastic mouthfeel.

Sample from a bottle. Pours a light gold color, with a small, off-white head. The nose is buttery, thick hops, with notes of pine sap, resin, biscuit dough, and lemon zest. The flavor is lightly dry and nicely bitter. Light to medium body, crisp, a little effervescent, and clean. This is a solidly done IPA, but the aroma is a little weak.

Sample from a bottle. Pours a clear, light orange, with a medium, bubbly head. The aroma is bready malts, floral hops, and not a whole lot else. Sweet and fairly bitter, and surprisingly well balanced. Medium body, clean, and a little flat. This is an easy, solid hoppy amber, but nothing special.

Sampled from a bottle. Pours a surprisingly dark orange color, with a creamy, tan head. The nose is bright orange peel and rose water, with some hints of biscuit and pine. Sweet up front, with a pleasant hop bitterness. Light to medium body, crisp, a little oily, and clingy. This is an okay pale ale base, but showcases the hops very nicely.
beer_name: Crazy Mountain Mountain Livin Pale Ale

review_blob: Sample from a bottle. Pale yellow color, with a small, beige head. The nose is wheat bread, ripe apples, resin, and light floral notes. Sweet and malty flavor, with a reasonable hop kick in the finish. Light body, crisp, and a little overly acidic. This is a solid hoppy pils.

330 mL bottle, bottled in 2011, bought recently from the bargain shelf at Coaltrain. Dark, cloudy reddish brown, with a big, foamy, tan head. Rich caramel, green apples, light lime, and some brown bread. Semi-sweet and malty, with a sharp, tart bite. Medium body, creamy, lightly acidic, and silky. Quite a nice sour brown, with a slightly dry flavor and luxurious mouthfeel. Doesnt look like the store aging didnt hurt too bad.

16 oz. can, from StFun. Black color, with a dark brown, fizzy head. The aroma is bittersweet chocolate, chicory, caramel, and light smoke and tobacco. Fairly dry and toasty, with a little bitterness. Medium body, sticky, and nicely grainy. This is a solid, delicious, and pleasantly aggressive and dry.

New batch that is marked as 6.4% ABV and 91 ABV. Pours a dark bronze color, with a medium, tan head. The nose is strong orange peel, tangerines, and some rye bread. The flavor is sweet and malty, with a good, citrusy, heavy bitterness. Medium to heavy body, syrupy, and thick. This is a strong IPA, but well balanced and nicely aromatic.

Sample in a flight at the brewery. Pours black, with a thin, fleeting, beige head. The nose is immense coconut oil, with some cocoa, syrup, and a touch of espresso. Very sweet flavor, with a light roasty bitterness. Light to medium body, oily, slick, and clean. According to Biff, when they do coconut beers, they mean it. He is absolutely correct; the coconut jumps out of this beer. Very tasty and creative.

Sample in a flight at the brewery. Pours a clear brown, with a small, tan head. The nose is maple syrup, licorice, pumpernickel, and light roasted grain. Sweet and malty flavor, with a mild bitterness. Medium body, smooth, sticky, and creamy. This is an odd ESB, with more spice and roast than Im used to. Not bad.

Sample in a flight at the brewery. Pale, unclear yellow, with a small, white head. Honeysuckle, strong lavender, white bread, ginger, biscuit dough, and salt. Sweet, light bitterness. Light body, effervescent, crisp, malty. This is a very fun, aromatic, refreshing, and unique beer.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2016

Sample. Pours a hazy, dark yellow, with a big, bubbly tan head. The nose is herbal and heavy juniper, with a good, sharp rye spice. Sweet and malty, with a mellow bitterness through the finish. Medium body, crisp and a little thin. This is a reasonable rye IPA, but nothing special.

Sample. Light gold color, with a big, bubbly, off-white head. The nose is biscuit, clover honey, mandarin oranges, and some interesting phenols. Sweet and yeasty, with a good dose of bitterness. Medium body, thick, and a little too thick. This is a fun beer, and very heavy for a wheat beer.

Sample. Dark brown color, with a small, beige head. The nose is pine and floral hops, with some good caramel and rye malts. A little sweet and sugary,,with a pleasant bitterness. Medium to heavy body, with a nice, chewy mouthfeel. This is a surprisingly balanced, easy, and tasty beer. Wouldnt have guessed it was gluten free.

Sample. Light, copper color, with a small, tan head. The nose is strong toffee and caramel, with a bit of mocha and cocoa. Cloying sweetness, and no balancing bitterness. Medium to heavy body, syrupy and clingy. This is an overly sweet beer, with more artificial flavoring than any quality stout base.

Sample in a flight at the brewery. Pale, hazy yellow, with a medium, off-white head. Wheat bread, light bananas, and a bit of floral hops. Sweet and a bit yeasty. Light body, acidic and thin. This is a poor, watery wheat beer.

12 oz. can, "thanks" to jackl. Clear, pale, bubbly yellow, with a medium, bubbly, off-white head that abates quickly. Nose of Saaz, corn syrup, and wet blankets. Sweet and syrupy, with no bitterness. At least the aftertaste is mild and not unpleasant. Light body, creamy, lightly effervescent, and a bit crisp. This is a poor, cheap lager. Overly sweet, with all the aroma that crappy adjuncts will get you.

16 oz. can from StFuns box full o tall boys. Clear, dark bronze color, with a big, frothy, beige head, and good lacing. The aroma is musty, earthy, with strong notes of hardwood and floral hops. Sweet and fairly malty, with a nice, smooth bitterness. Medium body, creamy, astringent, and pretty clean. This is a solid, clean, delicious IPA.
beer_name: Sun King Fistful of Hops Blue (2016)

review_blob: 16 oz. can, in a free box from StFun. Pours a clear, copper color, with a big, bubbly, off-white head. The nose is caramel and light toffee, pine and a touch of charred oak. Sweet, with some fruity phenols, and a mellow bitterness through the finish. Light to medium body, creamy, lightly astringent, and a bit flat. This is a fun, malty, easy beer.

16 oz. can, in a free box from StFun. Brilliant, clear, bronze-orange color, with a big, foamy, off-white head. The nose is bitter orange peel, caramel, rye, and some abrasive resin or pine sap. Sweet and malty up front, with an unpleasantly harsh bitterness that lingers long through the finish. Medium body, acerbic, sticky, and grainy. This is a nicely aromatic IPA, but the flavor is unbalanced. Not too bad, but not my favorite.

Pint at the brewery. Pale, clear yellow, with a medium, foamy, white head that leaves thick lacing. The nose is straw, bananas, lemon zest, and a musty character. Sweet, with a subtle bitterness and just a hint of sour. Light to medium body, crisp, sticky, and lightly carbonated. This is a nice, easy saison, with a lovely, balanced flavor.

Pint on nitro at the brewery. Black, with a medium, tan head and thick lacing. Subdued nose of watery coffee, baking chocolate, peat, and syrup. Sweet and malty up front, with a nice bitterness in the finish. Medium body, creamy, lightly astringent, and thin. This is a weak, thin stout.

On tap at the brewery. Pours black, with a small, off-white head and good lacing. The nose is lemon peel, milk chocolate, apple, and a distinct note of root beer. Sweet up front, with a light bitterness and tartness through the finish. Medium body, creamy, acidic, and smooth. An interesting and surprisingly delicious beer.
beer_name: Trinity You Never Even Call Me By My Name

review_blob: Sample on tap at the brewery. Clear, light pink color, with some bubbles. The nose is cherries, wheat, and cloves. Sweet and sugary, with a nice, crisp tart bite. Light to medium body, lightly acidic, crisp, and clean. This is a sharp and refreshing cherry sour, but isnt very complex.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a small, tan head. The nose is strong pecans and toffee, with some cocoa, maple syrup, and black bread. Cloying sweet and malty, with no bitterness. Medium to heavy body, syrupy, malty, and creamy. This is a solid, sweet, and tasty nut brown, but could use a little more balance in the flavor.

375 mL bottle. Pours a milky yellow, with a big, firm, frothy, white head. The nose is lemonade, orange peel, light leather, sage, and cream. Sweet and citrusy up front, with a good tart acidity through the finish. Light bitterness, but it cuts the sour flavor very well. Medium body, very acidic, smooth, lively, and clean. This is a wonderful beer that shows off a glorious hop aroma. Very well balanced, easy, yet complex.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a murky brown, with a very small, off-white head the promptly fizzles away. The nose is toasted oak, vanilla, tart cherries, cloves, peat, and lemons. Sweet up front, with a strong, even, and pleasant sour flavor through the finish. Medium to heavy body, sticky, warming and boozy, and very clingy. A wonderful exhibition of bourbon and sour cherries that is immediately delicious. The flavors open up as it warms, and it gets smoky and more complex. This is how all bourbon barrel aged beers should be done!
beer_name: Avery Barrel-Aged Series 27 - Insula multos Collibus

review_blob: 12 oz. can. Pours dark brown, with a thin, tan head. The aroma is bitter walnuts, caramel, bittersweet chocolate, and tart cherries. Sweet and malty, a bit bitter, with a slightly off sour flavor. Medium body, syrupy, and a little watery. This is an aromatic scotch ale, but I mustve let it sit in the fridge too long.

Sample from a bottle. Pours a hazy brown, with a small, foamy, beige head. The nose is licorice, caramel, burnt toast, and chalk. Sweet and malty flavor. Medium body, a little thin, and smooth. Overall, this is a weak porter, with some fairly unpleasant aromas and a weak palate.

Sample from a bottle. Hazy red color, with a small, off-white head. The nose is distinctly raspberry, and it is hard to get anything else. Maybe some coriander, banana, and caramel. Sweet and fruity, with a bit of hop bitterness that cuts the sweetness down a bit. Medium body, acidic, crisp, and a little clingy. Overall, this is a very aggressively fruited beer, but done quite well.
